section.title: Audience
section.para: This document is intended for individuals with system administrator-level knowledge of CentOS or Red Hat Enterprise Linux. In particular, it assumes basic experience with system installation and configuration, RPM package management, XML file creation and editing, basic web server management, system automation using BASH or other scripting languages, and a basic familiarity with version control systems.

section.title: What's Not Covered
section.para: This manual complements several CentOS Studio documents. The "Installation Instructions" and "Getting Started Guide" provide basic information about obtaining and installing CentOS Studio and creating a basic CentOS solution. The "Repository Definition File Reference" (SDFR) contains the syntax for solution definition elements and attributes. Finally, CentOS Studio has a set of man pages explaining the centosstudio command, its options and the CentOS Studio configuration file, centosstudio.conf. This manual contains references to all four throughout the text.
These CentOS Studio documents are available at the CentOS Studio website.

section.title: How to Read
section.para: The intent of the manual is to help you use CentOS Studio effectively to build and maintain solutions, and to use solutions to install and update client machines. This manual takes a top-down approach, explaining the concepts before giving steps, commands and code examples that you can use to build, deploy and enhance your own solutions.

section.title: Conventions Used
section.para: The document conventions are alphabetically listed below.

listitem.para: The Caution tag flags issues of importance.

caution.para: Using the 'dd' command to copy the diskboot.img file onto a USB key will destroy existing data on the device.

listitem.para: Command names in CentOS Studio or function names in other programs appear throughout the document.

Elements and attributes in XML are referred to by their XPath equivalents. The active node is always considered to be the root, solution; thus, the first element in the XPath expression is the top-level element, while subsequent elements/attributes are its children. Top-level elements in the SDFR and their child elements use the parent/child/child format, while @attribute-names are preceded by an @ symbol. The assumed parent element is solution. For more details on XPath syntax, see XML Path Language.

listitem.para: Filenames, folder names, directory trees and file extensions all use a monospace format.

note.para: The top-level elements can be in any order in the solution definition.
